question.title: Disable Camel interpretation of special characters completely
question.body:
I have got Camel code that manipulate weird strings (TM), which is to say, strings that contain brackets, and it makes Camel choke with errors such as

2025-04-22 16:56:15,987 ERROR [org.apa.cam.qua.mai.CamelMainRuntime] (main) Failed to start application: org.apache.camel.FailedToCreateRouteException: Failed to create route actualRouteId at: >>> To[log:thisIs{{broken}}completely] <<< in route: Route(actualRouteId)[From[direct:someRoute] -> [To[log:thisI... because of Failed to resolve endpoint: log:thisIs{{broken}}completely due to: Property with key [broken] not found in properties from text: log:thisIs{{broken}}completely

This happens in various scenarios:

  • logging those strings (using the Camel Log component, or "to(log:myBrokenString)" where myBrokenString is something like 'thisIs{{broken}}completely' (brackets)
  • mapping those strings to beans using an SQL query and something like .setBody(simple(mySqlQuery)) + .toD("jdbc:outputType=SelectList&outputClass=my.wonderful.class") for mapping

I would like to disable interpretation completely for data that is supplied from an external source such as a database that user can interact with. Is there any way to do that ? I have searched Camel documentation and have found nothing that works.

Please note that, according to the documentation, I have got 2 issues:

  • for logging, the log message is interpreted as a "Simple" language String. Which allows for property placeholders ? ({{ and }})
  • for the jdbc thing, my "my.wonderful.class" class is a "CsvRecord" and contains multiple @DataField fields. But I don't think it matters.

question_comments.body: If your goal is just to check and fail a request when it contains a property lookup string you could go as simple as to write a Processor or route bean that evaluates whether the input string contains property placeholder characters and throw an exception if it does. Example: from(...).routeId("...").process((exchange) -> { if (exchange.getMessage().getIn().getBody(String.class).contain‌​s("{{")) { throw new IllegalArgumentException("..."); } }.log("...");

Instead of using plain strings as endpoint configuration I'd suggest to use EndpoinRouteBuilder and its DSL to reduce the chance of typing errors and invalid arguments. Instead of .to("log:...") you can also write .log(...) which makes the route definition easier to read. Camel will also only resolve "{{property}}" properties from either system, env or application properties by default AFAIK. You could try to use "simple" like that .log("thisIs${properties:broken}completely") to let simple try and resolve that property for you

I could probably do that but I don't even know where to find such a list of characters that are special to Camel.   Also please not that .log(level, myString) does not make use of URIs. It uses Camel DSL and plain, typed Java objects.
Camel depends a lot on URIs with custom schemes. I would guess you probably should URI encode special characters or otherwise you hit those URI misinterpretations you currently see.
